answers.a: Food-grade paraffin wax (E905CII) is considered non-toxic at permitted levels; it is largely inert and poorly absorbed. Regulatory specs limit impurities such as polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, and excessive ingestion may act as a laxative but is not expected to be poisonous.
Paraffin wax is a refined mixture of long-chain saturated hydrocarbons derived from petroleum. In foods, E905CII is used as a glazing or coating agent to provide shine and moisture protection.

answers.q: what is paraffin wax made of
answers.a: It consists mainly of straight-chain alkanes roughly 20–35 carbons long that are crystallized and purified from petroleum distillates, then further refined (e.g., deoiled, filtered) to meet food-grade specifications.

Yes—food-grade paraffin wax is allowed as a surface treatment on fruits, confectionery, and cheese, and in chewing gum bases. It passes through the digestive tract undigested, so only small incidental amounts should be consumed.
In foods it provides gloss, reduces stickiness, and slows moisture loss on products like candy, fruit, and cheese; it can also function as a release agent and component of chewing gum bases.

answers.q: what does paraffin wax do for feet
answers.a: In spa treatments melted paraffin wax traps heat and moisture, softening skin and offering temporary relief for stiff joints. Use cosmetic- or medical-grade wax at safe temperatures to avoid burns.

answers.q: where does paraffin wax come from
answers.a: It is produced from petroleum: heavy distillate fractions are de-waxed, then the crystalline wax is deoiled, filtered, and sometimes hydrogenated to yield purified food-grade material.

Look for food- or cosmetic-grade paraffin at bakery and confectionery suppliers, candle-making retailers, craft stores, or specialty ingredient distributors. For industrial quantities, contact wax processors or chemical suppliers that certify food-grade compliance.

Small amounts of food-grade paraffin wax are acceptable when present as a coating or in chewing gum, but it has no nutritional value and large quantities could cause digestive discomfort. Ensure the product is explicitly food-grade before ingesting incidental amounts.

Refiners chill petroleum distillates to crystallize waxes, filter and press out the crystals, remove residual oil, and further purify (e.g., clay treating, hydrogenation, filtration) to meet food-grade specifications for E905CII.
